Jan McFarlane
Bishop of Repton

Personal details

Janet Elizabeth "Jan" McFarlane (born 25 November 1964) is a British Church of England bishop and former Speech and Language Therapist. She has been the Bishop of Repton (the suffragan bishop of the Diocese of Derby) since her consecration as a bishop on 29 June 2016;[1][2] and additionally Acting Bishop of Derby since 31 August 2018.[3] She was previously Diocesan Director of Communications in the Diocese of Norwich from 1999 and Archdeacon of Norwich from 2009.

Contents

  • 1 Early life and education
  • 2 Ordained ministry
    • 2.1 Episcopal ministry
  • 3 Personal life
  • 4 Selected works
  • 5 References

Early life and education[edit]

Jan McFarlane was born on 25 November 1964 in Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire, England.[4][5][6] She was educated at Blythe Bridge High School, a state secondary school in Blythe Bridge near Stoke-on-Trent.[7] She studied at the University of Sheffield, graduating with a Bachelor of Medical Science (BMedSci) degree in 1987.[4] She then worked as a Speech Therapist in the National Health Service and lived in North Staffordshire.[8] She specialised in teaching deaf children to speak.[5]

Having been selected for ordination, Jan McFarlane underwent a number of years of formation. She studied theology at St John's College, Durham, and graduated from the University of Durham with a Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree in 1992.[4] She then underwent a further year of training at Cranmer Hall, Durham, an open evangelical Anglican theological college,[4][9] completing a Diploma in Ministry (DipMin) in 1993.[6]

Ordained ministry[edit]

McFarlane was ordained in the Church of England as a deacon in 1993 at Lichfield Cathedral.[4][9] From 1993 to 1994, she served as parish deacon in the Stafford Team Ministry in the Diocese of Lichfield.[4] She was ordained as a priest in 1994.[4] She was one of the first female priests as 1994 was the first year that the Church of England ordained women to the priesthood.[10] From 1994 to 1996, she remained in the Stafford to serve her curacy as part of the Stafford Team Ministry.[4][9] From 1996 to 1999, she was a chaplain and minor canon of Ely Cathedral in the Diocese of Ely.[4]

In 1999, she moved to the Diocese of Norwich to take up the appointment of Diocesan Director of Communications.[4] From 2001 to 2009, she was additionally chaplain to Graham James, the Bishop of Norwich.[4][9] She was selected as the next Archdeacon of Norwich in 2008.[8] On 15 March 2009, she was installed as Archdeacon in Norwich Cathedral.[9] Upon her appointment, she became one of only nine female archdeacons out of a total of 112 in the Church of England and the first in her diocese.[8] From 2015, she also served as Warden of Readers for the diocese.[11]

Jan McFarlane was first elected to the General Synod of the Church of England in 2005.[7] She is a supporter of the ordination of women as bishops.[12] She was a member of the General Synod that approved the consecration of women to the episcopate.[13]

Episcopal ministry[edit]

On 26 February 2016, Jan McFarlane was announced as the next Bishop of Repton, suffragan bishop in the Diocese of Derby.[10] She was consecrated a bishop by Justin Welby, Archbishop of Canterbury, on 29 June 2016.[1][2] She was welcomed into the Diocese of Derby as Bishop of Repton on 7 September 2016, during service at Derby Cathedral.[14]

Personal life[edit]

In 2004, McFarlane married Andrew Ridoutt.[6] Her husband works as a television cameraman.[10]

In February 2014, McFarlane was diagnosed with breast cancer. As part of her treatment, she underwent surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy. She shared her story with a local newspaper, the Eastern Daily Press, and "urged other cancer patients to not hide away from the disease".[15]

Selected works[edit]

  • McFarlane, Jan (2009). Pocket prayers for Advent and Christmas. London: Church House Publishing. ISBN 9780715141960. 
  • McFarlane, Jan; Gooder, Paula; Baines, Nick; Kiddle, John; Cottrell, Stephen (2010). Ready Steady Slow: an Advent calendar to unwind with. London: Church House Publishing. ISBN 9780715142219. 
  • McFarlane, Jan (2012). Pocket prayers of blessing. London: Church House Publishing. ISBN 9780715142394.
